task.title: Safety Mechanisms and Controls

othermeta.name: shortdesc
othermeta.content: Overview of mechanical and electronic safety mechanisms used to protect personnel and equipment on conveyors.

othermeta.name: entities
othermeta.content: emergency stop;interlock switch;protective guards;control unit;limit switches

othermeta.name: usecase
othermeta.content: define safety mechanisms and control requirements for conveyors

step.cmd: There is a lockable main switch on the door of the belt conveyor control cabinet that is used to switch off the power supply to the belt conveyor.

ul.li: When the switch is switched to “Off”, the belt conveyor will not work and no movements will occur.
Lockout-tagout-verify the main switch with a padlock for the entire period of the work to prevent unwanted reactivation. Follow plant procedures.

note.p: Even after a main switch has been switched off, the following circuits remain live (if present) for the corresponding control cabinet: Cabinet lighting, control cabinet socket, cabinet ventilation.
The circuit diagrams for the electronic components can be found in the electrical documentation.

step.cmd: The belt conveyor possesses an emergency stop system that shuts down all functions and movements. In an emergency, the belt conveyor can be stopped using an emergency stop cord on the conveyor.

ul.li: Do not use an emergency stop cord to switch the belt conveyor off under normal conditions.

note.p: Emergency stop switches and cords do not disconnect the belt conveyor from the power supply. All machine parts that are live during normal operation continue to be live after an emergency stop has been triggered.

step.cmd: he rotary survey sends pulses to the controller to indicate that the tensioning pulley is turning. These pulses are evaluated by the PLC or a control device (except in manual operation).

ul.li: The rotary survey is an incremental encoder (inductive proximity switch) (1) and cam switch (2) that are mounted at the end of the tensioning pulley shaft.
If the pulses are not received, the belt conveyor will be switched off after a time delay in order to protect it against damage.

note.p: If the rotary survey triggers, it is necessary to perform the following steps.

ul.li: Identify the reason why the rotary survey triggered.
Eliminate the reason that caused the rotary survey to trigger.
Acknowledge the error message at the control cabinet (blue pushbutton).
The belt conveyor can now be restarted.

step.cmd: he belt conveyor is equipped with a start-up alarm device (siren and/or flashing warning light).

ul.li: When the start pushbutton is pressed, the start-up alarm device sounds and/or is visible for 10 seconds.
The belt conveyor does not start until this period has elapsed. This ensures that anyone in the area of the belt conveyor has enough time to move away from the danger area.

note.p: It must be possible to hear and/or see the alarm signal along the entire length of the belt conveyor.

step.cmd: Most of the functional components of the belt conveyor are covered by protective housings and covers. These prevent body parts from penetrating into moving machine parts, and prevent injury due to mechanical components.

note.p: The belt conveyor may be equipped with a spindle tensioning station—although Zippe did not indicate whether this equipment was installed for Streator. (See section 5.1.2 “Option: vertical screw-operated tensioning station” in the vendor manual.)

ul.li: In this case, protective grilles (1) cover the spindle tensioning station in order to prevent persons from reaching in or similar actions.
Intermediate plates (2) cover the danger area from above.

step.cmd: The drive station is covered by a hood construction (1 and 2). On belt conveyors, if the frame area after the top hood is not covered or is constructed without continuous guide gutters, then this area is covered by additional protective housings (3).

ul.li: The tensioning station is covered by a hood-type cover (4). A cover at the inner belt scraper (5) prevents anyone from reaching into the tensioning pulley’s pull-in area from above.

If the belt conveyor is installed at a height so that the bottom belt is located at a height of 700 mm to 2500 mm above the installation level, then the area below the tensioning pulley is equipped with a protective housing (6). In this case, the bottom belt is also covered by protective housings (7) in the working areas and areas where persons stand or pass by.
Protective covers (8) at the guide gutters prevent body parts from being crushed and pulled in. Protective cages (9) at the return rollers prevents the rollers from falling down.
Because there is clearance of at least 50 mm between the conveyor belt and the return roller, these are not covered.

step.cmd: A protective grille (1) with a 30 x 30-mm mesh is affixed to the control opening in the drive station cover in order to prevent anyone from reaching into the belt conveyor.

ul.li: The control opening is located in the top hood of the belt conveyor drive station in order to permit observation of the machine’s movements during operation.

note.p: When the control opening is open, there is a danger of injury, especially to the eyes. Wear protective glasses. Keep the control opening closed.

step.cmd: The belt conveyor has warning signs for:

ul.li: Dangerous electrical voltage
Danger of pulling-in and crushing
Danger of pulling-in and squeezing
